abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: In this work, the self-collimating phenomenon in two-dimensional rhombic-lattice photonic crystals is discussed in detail. The equi-frequency contours of a rhombic-lattice rod-type photonic crystal structure are calculated with the plane wave expansion method for different lattice angles and rod radii. A broad range of flat and open equi-frequency contours is found. A rhombic-lattice photonic crystal made of 301 × 21 silicon rods (n = 3.5) in air is presented as an illustration to demonstrate the broadband all-angle self-collimation. The bandwidth for all-angle self-collimation is verified to be 17.42% of the central frequency by simulations based on the finite-difference time-domain method. The all-angle self-collimation is found to be polarization-independent and the frequency for simultaneous TM and TE all-angle self-collimation is identified and verified by finite-difference time-domain simulations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Photonic crystals (PCs) are periodic dielectric structures [1–3]. In the past two decades, PCs have attracted a lot of attention due to their extraordinary ability to control the propagation of light. Various optical devices based on PCs have been explored, such as waveguides [4, 5], filters [6], resonators [5], beamsplitters [7, 8] and fibers [9].

The bandgap properties of PCs have been extensively studied in the past. In recent years, more and more interest has been attracted by the unusual dispersion properties of PCs [10, 11], such as superprism [12], negative refraction [13, 14] and self-collimation [15, 16]. Among these, the self-collimation in PCs provides a brand new way of confining light propagation besides the conventional PC waveguide. A self-collimated light beam can propagate without diffraction in the PC. Many useful devices have been proposed based on the self-collimation effect, including virtual waveguides [17], interferometers [18], beam bends and splitters [7, 19], polarization beamsplitters [20], resonators [21], optical switches [22], optical routers [23], optical interconnectors [24], etc.

Light propagation in a PC structure is governed by its dispersion surfaces, which provide a visual representation in the k-space of the spatial variation of the spectral properties. Incident light propagates in directions normal to the dispersion surface. A cross section of the dispersion surface at a constant frequency is referred to as an equi-frequency contour (EFC). EFCs record eigenfrequencies of Maxwell’s equations in k-space and provide visual information to predict the light propagation. The direction of light propagation is given by the group velocity vg = ∇kω(k), which is perpendicular to the EFCs. The so-called self-collimating phenomenon occurs where the EFC corresponding to a frequency is flat. The EFCs can be obtained by casting Maxwell’s equations into an eigenvalue problem and solving with computational electromagnetic techniques, e.g. the plane wave expansion (PWE) method.

High collimating efficiency is demanded by increasing numbers of applications. In recent works several efforts have been made to improve the performance of self-collimation, e.g. broadening the bandwidth of working frequency [25–27], making it polarization-independent [28, 29], reducing the reflection on PC–air interface [30–32], and expanding the incident angle range [25, 32–34].

It is known that the wide angular range of self-collimation helps to enhance collimating efficiency. Based on this concept, the so-called ‘all-angle self-collimation’ was proposed and studied. In such a case light incident at any angle, including an angle near 90°, can be collimated. This phenomenon is illustrated in figure 1. In conventional PCs as illustrated in figure 1(a), the incident angle for self-collimation is usually limited to a finite small range. All-angle self-collimation can be realized in two situations [25]. In one situation the flat part of the EFC is longer than the diameter of the corresponding air contour as shown in figure 1(b). In the other situation the EFC is flat and open as shown in figure 1(c). Comparing with the flat long EFC, the flat open EFC is more desirable because all-angle self-collimation occurs regardless of the size of the corresponding air contour in this case.

caption.p: The schematics of the EFCs in PCs (bold line) and the corresponding air contours (circle). The arrows indicate directions of light propagation. (a) Self-collimation with limited angle. (b) All-angle self-collimation on flat, long EFCs. (c) All-angle self-collimation on flat, open EFCs.

sec.p: It is found that the shape of the EFCs in the self-collimation frequency range mimics the shape of the first Brillouin zone (FBZ) of PCs [35]. For example, PCs of square lattice possess an EFC of rounded square shape, and PCs of triangular lattice possess an EFC of rounded hexagonal shape in the self-collimation frequency range. For such similarity, a longer flat EFC is likely found in a PC with an FBZ of narrower reciprocal space. Since it is difficult for PCs of high symmetry to produce broadband flat EFC, an effective way to achieve this is to lower symmetry of the PC structure.

Based on these concerns, some particular structures have been proposed for all-angle self-collimation. Xu et al realized all-angle self-collimation with a narrow relative bandwidth in a PC of rectangular lattice [33]. Liang et al improved the relative bandwidth of all-angle self-collimation to about 10.87% in a PC of square lattice with elliptical rods [27], and Chuang et al improved the relative bandwidth to about 17.00% in a PC of hybrid structure with elliptical rods [25]. According to Chuang et al’s design, the PC structure is composed of two different lattice structures shifted in position, with each lattice made of elliptical dielectric rods of different sizes. The minimum length of the minor semi-axis of the elliptical rods is 57.4 nm. The complexity of Chuang et al’s design restricts its use in practical applications.

In this paper, we propose a simple PC of rod-type rhombic-lattice structure that can realize broadband operation of all-angle self-collimation. The relative bandwidth of this PC is about 17.42% which is as broad as that of Chuang et al’s design but is achieved with a much simpler structure. In addition, the concept of polarization-independent self-collimation [28, 29] is extended to all-angle operation in the proposed rhombic-lattice structure.

sec.title: Geometry of the rhombic lattices
sec.p: To obtain the EFCs of the rhombic-lattice PCs, the geometry and the FBZ of the lattice must be acquired firstly. We consider the geometry of the rhombic lattices in detail. The proposed PC of rhombic lattice consists of dielectric rods with permittivity of ϵa scatter in a uniform background medium with permittivity of ϵb as shown in figure 2. The lattice angle θ is defined in the range of 0° < θ ≤ 90°. To avoid the overlap of the adjacent rods, the radius of the rods is confined to r ≤ asin(θ/2) when θ∈(0°,60°] and r ≤ 0.5a when θ∈[60°,90°], where a is the lattice constant.

sec.title: Broadband all-angle self-collimation
sec.p: We consider a 2D PC structure with silicon rods (n = 3.5) arranged in a rhombic lattice in air as illustrated in figure 2(a). The radius of the rods is restricted to r ≤ asin(θ/2) to avoid overlap of the neighboring rods. To achieve all-angle self-collimation, we calculate the EFCs for different lattice angles and radii of the rods by means of a plane wave expansion, using a freely available software package [36]. A total number of 4096 plane waves are used in each calculation. The calculations show that all-angle self-collimation occurs when the lattice angle is within the range from 25° to 40°. Within this angle range, flat open EFCs exist for the TM mode in both band 2 and band 3, but the bandwidth of that in band 2 is very narrow. Meanwhile, flat open EFCs exist for the TE mode only in band 2 with a narrow bandwidth. In the following the study is concentrated on EFCs of the TM mode in band 3. If the lattice angle θ is greater than 40°, the flat open EFCs tend to disappear, while if θ is less than 25°, the adjacent bands tend to overlap with each other, and which gives rise to multimode operation.

In order to optimize parameters of the structure for broadband all-angle self-collimation, the impact of lattice angle and radius of the rods on the bandwidth of flat EFCs is studied. The lattice angle θ is varied from 26° to 38°; and the radius of the rods are varied from 0.16a to asin(θ/2). The relative bandwidth as a function of the lattice angle and the radius is shown in figure 3(a). It is evident that broader bandwidth is obtainable when the lattice angle is between 30° and 34°. The highest bandwidth of about 18.87% is achieved when the lattice angle is θ = 32° and the radius of the rods is r = 0.25a.

caption.p: (a) The relative bandwidth of flat EFCs of TM mode in the third band varies with lattice angle and radius of the rods. The PC consists of silicon rods (n = 3.5) arranged in a rhombic lattice in air. (b) The dispersion surface of TM mode in the third band for θ = 32° and r = 0.25a, and (c) the corresponding EFCs.

sec.p: Shown in figures 3(b) and (c) are respectively the dispersion surface of the TM mode in the third band for θ = 32° and r = 0.25a, and the corresponding EFCs of the optimized structure. From figure 3(b) it is quite apparent that a large part of the dispersion surface is flat with respect to variation of ky. All-angle self-collimation may occur in these regions. The frequency range of flat EFCs can be acquired by analyzing the corresponding EFCs as shown in figure 3(c). Flat, open EFCs occur in the frequency range from 0.475c/a to 0.574c/a, where c is the speed of light in vacuum. The relative bandwidth is 18.87%.

The wide bandwidth of the flat open EFCs implies that broadband operation of all-angle self-collimation is possible. To verify this, numerical simulations are performed to simulate light propagation in the proposed structure. The structure consists of 301 × 21 silicon rods arranged in a rhombic lattice in air along the ΓX and ΓN directions, as illustrated in figure 4(a). The lattice angle is θ = 32° and the radius of the rods is r = 0.25a. The lattice constant is set to a = 820 nm and the radius of the rods is set to 205 nm. The size of the structure is 71.09 μm and 15.76 μm in the ΓX and ΓN directions, respectively. The 2D finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method is employed in our simulations [37]. Perfectly matched layer (PML) absorbing boundary conditions are applied surrounding the computation domain. An Ez-polarized Gaussian beam with a width of 4a (3.28 μm) is launched into the PC from air at a distance of 3a (2.46 μm) away from the left-hand side of the PC–air interface. Waves of different frequencies between 0.475c/a (λ = 1726 nm) and 0.574c/a (λ = 1426 nm) are incident from different angles of γ = 0°, 45°, and 85°, respectively. Shown in figures 4(b)–(e) are the Ez field distributions in the PC structure at four typical frequencies, namely f = 0.475c/a (λ = 1726 nm), 0.482c/a (λ = 1701 nm), 0.528c/a (λ = 1553 nm) and 0.574c/a (λ = 1429 nm), respectively.

caption.p: (a) The schematic of the rhombic-lattice PC structure with 301 rods in the ΓX direction and 21 rods in the ΓN direction. The lattice angle is θ = 32° and the radius of the rods are r = 0.25a. (b)–(e) The FDTD simulations of steady-state field distributions of the Ez component. An Ez-polarized Gaussian beam with a width of 4a is launched from a distance of 3a with different incident angles of γ = 0°, 45°and 85°. The dashed lines represent PC–air interfaces. Frequencies of incident waves are (b) f = 0.475c/a, (c) f = 0.482c/a, (d) f = 0.528c/a and (e) f = 0.574c/a.

sec.p: The simulations confirm the operation of all-angle self-collimation in the frequency region from 0.482c/a to 0.574c/a, with a relative bandwidth of about 17.42%. From these FDTD studies it is found that frequencies between 0.475c/a and 0.482c/a are not suitable for application of all-angle self-collimation. For these frequencies the corresponding EFCs have two branches: one of the branches is flat and open while the other branch is curved, as shown in figure 3(c). Since the self-collimation in this frequency range is accompanied with another mode, the incident light beam diverges in propagation. As shown in figure 4(b), small radiations scattered to other directions are clearly visible besides the main collimated light beam, especially when the incident angle approaches 85°. The coexistence of two modes ceases to exist as frequency increases beyond 0.482c/a and, as a consequence, the divergent beam in the PC disappears. Shown in figures 4(c)–(e) are the FDTD simulations of wave propagations in the PC for the lower minimum frequency 0.482c/a, the middle frequency 0.528c/a and the maximum frequency 0.574c/a, respectively. These simulations clearly demonstrate that all incident light beams are well collimated along the ΓX direction, even when the incident angle is as large as 85°. Angles larger than 85° are not tested due to their large inclination but, based on the analysis of flat open EFCs and from the observation of figure 4, it can be predicted that the light beam can still be collimated along the ΓX direction as the incident angle approaches 90°.

The transmission spectra of beams incident at different angles of γ = 0°, 45°and 85° are investigated numerically. The contact width of the incident light beam with the PC increases with the incident angle and is given by L = w/cos(γ), where w is the beam width and γ is the incident angle. In our simulations, the source beam width is 4a and the contact width will be 45.90a if the incident angle is 85°. The simulations for the study of the transmission spectrum are performed in a PC with a long width along the ΓN direction as shown in figure 5(a). The structure consists of 41 rods (11.30a) along the ΓX direction and 56 rods (53.83a) along the ΓN direction. The source is aimed at the center (marked 1 in figure 5(a)) of the left PC–air interface of the structure when the incident angle is 0° and at the bottom corner (marked 2 in figure 5(a)) when the incident angle is 45° or 85°. Two monitors of the same width, named M1 and M2, are placed at 0.5a (410 nm) away from the left and right PC–air interface, respectively. The normalized transmission is defined as the output power which is detected by M2 divided by the input power which is read out by M1. Figure 5(b) shows the normalized transmission as a function of frequency for different incident angles. It is observed that the transmission oscillates with the frequency. This is mainly because the reflection is modulated by the PC–air interface and shows a strong Fabry–Perot-like phenomenon. The reflections can be reduced by some methods, such as surface modification and impedance matching [30–32], but this is beyond the scope of this paper. It is also noticed that the transmission decreases as the incident angle increases, and this trend is more evident when the incident angle is close to 85°. It’s comprehensible that reflection is strengthened with the increases of incident angle.

caption.p: (a) The schematic PC structure for transmission study, which consists of 41 rods along the ΓX direction and 56 rods along the ΓN direction. The lattice angle is 32° and the radius of the rods is 0.25a. (b) Transmission spectra for TM mode for different incident angles γ = 0°, 45°and 85°.

sec.p: The inverted PC structure which consists of air holes in a silicon background is also investigated. The broadest bandwidth found for all-angle self-collimation is about 8.26% in the fourth band for TE mode, which occurs when the lattice angle is 28° and the radius of the rods is r = 0.21a. This bandwidth (8.26%) is less than half of the bandwidth of the TM mode (17.42%) in a rod-type PC (8.26%/17.42%–47.42%).

sec.title: Polarization-independent all-angle self-collimation
sec.p: Simultaneous all-angle self-collimation for both TM and TE modes, i.e. the issue of polarization-independent all-angle self-collimation, is explored numerically in this study. The polarization-independent self-collimation is easy to realize in a square-lattice PC and has been frequently studied. But the polarization-independent all-angle self-collimation is seldom studied. This is because that symmetry of the PC structures involved in all-angle self-collimation is usually low. Due to this low symmetry, the TM mode and TE mode of the same band will obviously experience different refractions in the PC. As a consequence, polarization-independent self-collimation is difficult to achieve for the given frequency region. But it is noticed that the flat, open EFCs can be designed to coexist simultaneously for both TM mode and TE mode in the neighboring bands for the same frequency. Shown in figures 6(a) and (b) are the third band EFCs for TM mode and the second band EFCs for TE mode of a rhombic-lattice PC. The parameters of the rhombic lattice are the same as those used in section 3, except that the radius of the rods is now r = 0.23a. It is observed that the EFCs for frequency 0.552c/a are flat and open for both the TM mode and TE mode. It indicates that polarization-independent all-angle self-collimation can be realized at this frequency (0.552c/a) in this structure.

caption.p: (a) The third band EFCs for TM mode and (b) the second band EFCs for TE mode of the designed PC. The PC consists of silicon rods (n = 3.5) arranged in a rhombic lattice in air. The lattice angle is θ = 32° and the radius of the rods is r = 0.23a.

sec.p: To verify the above discussed polarization-independent all-angle self-collimation, light propagation in this structure is simulated with the FDTD method. An Ez-polarized and an Hz-polarized Gaussian beam with a width of 4a at frequency f = 0.552c/a are respectively launched from a distance of 3a (2.46 μm) into the PC from air at different incident angles γ = 0°, 45°and 85°. Shown in figures 7(a) and (b) are the steady-state field distributions of the Ez component and Hz component respectively. It can be seen clearly that the Ez-polarized and the Hz-polarized incident light beams are both well collimated along the ΓX direction even when the incident angle is as large as 85°. The simulations demonstrate that polarization-independent all-angle self-collimation can be realized at some frequencies by choosing the proper parameters for the rhombic-lattice PC structure.

caption.p: The steady-state field distributions of the (a) Ez component of the TM wave and (b) Hz component of the TE wave simulated with the FDTD method. The lattice angle is θ = 32° and the radius of the rods is r = 0.23a. The sources are an Ez-polarized Gaussian beam for (a) and an Hz-polarized Gaussian beam for (b). Width of the incident beams is 4a and frequency of the waves is f = 0.552c/a. Incident angles are γ = 0°, 45°and 85° for both TM and TE modes. The dashed lines represent the PC–air interfaces.

sec.p: The transmission spectra of both TM and TE modes are computed as shown in figures 8(a) and (b), respectively. The PC structure is the same as that used in figure 5(a), except that the radius of the rods is reset to r = 0.23a. The spectrum of the TM mode is like that shown in figure 5(b). On the other hand, the spectrum of the TE mode has an obviously distinctive feature. It is noticed that the oscillation in the transmission spectra of the TE mode is not as dramatic as that of the TM mode. Similar to the TM mode, the transmission spectra of the TE mode decreases as the incident angle increases, but the angular dependence of the transmission spectra of the TE mode is found to be not as strong as that of the TM mode. It is also observed that, when the incident angle γ = 0°, the normalized transmission rate has a peak at frequency f = 0.554c/a, which is in the vicinity of the frequency for all-angle self-collimation. It can be seen from both the EFCs and the transmission spectrum of the TE mode that the bandwidth for polarization-independent all-angle self-collimation is quite narrow and further investigation is needed for enhanced bandwidth for future application. A wide bandwidth operation of all-angle self-collimation for both TM mode and TE mode is always appreciated.

caption.p: Transmission spectra for (a) TM mode and (b) TE mode for different incident angles γ = 0°, 45°and 85°. The lattice angle is θ = 32° and the radius of the rods is r = 0.23a.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In summary, we have studied the phenomena of all-angle self-collimation in PCs of rhombic lattice in detail. The EFCs are calculated with the PWE method, and the impact of lattice angle and radius of the rods on bandwidth of flat EFCs is investigated. Based on theoretical analysis of EFCs, a rhombic-lattice structure of PCs that provides a 17.42% bandwidth of all-angle self-collimation is designed. FDTD simulations are performed. It is demonstrated that incident light beams in a broad frequency range from 0.482c/a to 0.574c/a can be well collimated even when the incident angle is as large as 85°. The polarization-independent all-angle self-collimation is spotted at frequency f = 0.552c/a and is confirmed numerically. Wide-angle operation and broadband wave guiding are two important issues. These works may help to improve collimating efficiency and be useful for future applications in integrated optics systems.
